comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The January 8, 1914 date inscribed on the Bain News Agency's negative is confusing, because the fight in San Francisco [Daly City] between Gunboat Smith and the Canadian newcomer, Arthur Pelkey, took place on January 1, as reported in the New York Times, in a story that appeared in the January 2 edition: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9D02E... Another Bain/LOC photo of the Gunboat Smith vs. Arthur Pelkey fight shows Pelkey knocked to the canvas in the fifteenth round, as the referee begins his count: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4669377234/in/photostream/] "After thirty seconds figiting in the fifteenth round Smith feinted with his left, then swung his right with lightning-like rapidity. The blow landed with a crash on Pelkey's unprotected jaw. Pelkey dropped with his eyes glassy. Mechanically he struggled to his feet at the count of nine and unsteadily assumed his fighting pose. A left and right applied similarly toppled him and he was out when Referee Griffin awarded the fight to Smith."

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Note to LOC: Your caption on this photo is incorrect. Correct spelling of name is "Pelkey." Correct date is January 1, 1914.

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: Wystan, Thanks for the information on this fight. We will expand and correct the information regarding the date and other details. I saw your note on the photo itself: "There appears to be a message here, printed in capital letters over the water." That white area along the back is actually a fence enclosing the ampitheater, and the text is an advertisement for Kissel Kars, it turns out. Kissel Kars was opening a new salesroom and service station in San Francisco not long after this fight, so they were advertising in the area. The text on the fence is straight from their ad in the San Francisco Chronicle, though it is quite hard to make out: Kissel Pleasure Kars Kissel Kommercial Kars Federal Trucks Ford Cars

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: That link to the Kissel ad in the San Francisco Chronicle goes thru ProQuest, and evidently (unless we obtain a note from teacher) is unavailable to us of the hoi polloi.

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: Wystan, I was afraid of that! Unfortunately, since it is a subscription database (ProQuest Historical Newspapers), it's not possible for me to grant access. It is a resource subscribed to by many larger research facilities and universities, though. At any rate, there is little substance in the link beyond what I quoted. The ad was published in the San Francisco Chronicle on Jan. 11, 1914, and is titled: Announcement of our Formal Opening, then begins: The Pacific Kissel Kar Branch cordially invites the public to call and inspect its new spacious salesroom and service station (the Largest on the Pacific Coast) during the week of January 12th to 17th... The four types of vehicles are arrayed on the left and right side of this main block of text. Sorry for any confusion with that link.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Pelkey was known then as the man who killed "White Hope" Luther McCarty (the so-called "White Heavyweight Champion" the year before in the boxing ring in Calgary, Alberta, Canada: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10A10F83B5F13738...
